part_of: Dutch Colonial Expansion in Southeast Asia

causes: Dutch East India Company (VOC) sought control over gold mines run by the Lanfang Republic.
Lanfang Republic, a Chinese-founded mining confederation, resisted Dutch economic dominance.
Conflict over taxation and mining rights escalated into armed conflict.
events_leading_up_to_war: Lanfang Republic, established in 1777 by Chinese Hakka miners, thrived independently.
Dutch expanded colonial control in Borneo in the mid-19th century.
Private Dutch military forces and mercenaries pressured local Chinese settlements.

treaties.name: Dutch Annexation of Lanfang
terms: Lanfang Republic disbanded and absorbed into the Dutch East Indies.
Chinese mining settlements placed under Dutch control.

territorial_changes: Dutch colonial authorities expanded control over West Borneo.
Former Lanfang territories were placed under direct Dutch rule.

entities: Local Dayak tribes allied with Lanfang
allies: Qing Dynasty (provided unofficial support but did not intervene militarily)
Local Malay sultanates supporting Dutch rule

private_military_companies_and_mercenari.name: Dutch Colonial Mercenaries
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.role: Recruited European and Malay fighters to suppress Lanfang resistance.
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.tactics: Used modern firearms and artillery against Chinese-held mining towns.

private_military_companies_and_mercenari.name: Chinese Mercenary Units
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.role: Lanfang Republic hired private Chinese warriors for self-defense.
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.tactics: Relied on guerrilla warfare and fortified strongholds.

Lanfang_Republic: Liu Asheng (last President of Lanfang Republic)
Dutch_East_Indies: General Johan van Swieten (Dutch colonial commander)
Private military contractors leading Dutch forces

Lanfang_Republic.tactics: Used jungle warfare, fortifications, and surprise raids.

Dutch_East_Indies.troops: 15,000+ including Dutch soldiers and private military forces.
Dutch_East_Indies.navy: Dutch gunboats used to blockade mining settlements.
Dutch_East_Indies.tactics: Employed scorched-earth policies and modern artillery bombardments.

Lanfang_Republic.dead_and_wounded: Several thousand Chinese settlers and mercenaries.

Dutch_East_Indies.dead_and_wounded: Few hundred Dutch soldiers and mercenaries.
Dutch_East_Indies.destruction: Dutch forts occasionally raided by Lanfang guerrillas.

major_battles.name: Siege of Mandor
major_battles.description: Dutch forces launched a full-scale assault on the Lanfang capital, leading to its downfall.
major_battles.outcome: Dutch victory, forcing Lanfang leaders to flee.

major_battles.name: Battle of the Gold Mines
major_battles.description: Lanfang mercenaries defended key mining operations, but were eventually overwhelmed.
major_battles.outcome: Dutch victory, securing complete control over Borneo’s gold trade.

texts.name: Lanfang Republic Records
texts.author: Hakka scholars
texts.details: Accounts of Lanfang’s resistance and governance.

texts.name: Dutch Colonial Archives
texts.author: Dutch colonial government
texts.details: Records of military strategies and trade conflicts.

archaeological_evidence.description: Site of Lanfang's former capital, destroyed by the Dutch.
Gold mining tools and weapons used by Lanfang forces.

political: Lanfang Republic ceased to exist, marking the end of Chinese self-rule in Borneo.
Dutch fully integrated West Borneo into their colonial empire.
long_term_effects: Chinese settlers in Borneo became economically dependent on Dutch authorities.
Inspired later nationalist movements among overseas Chinese communities.

military: One of the first recorded wars involving private Chinese mercenaries defending an autonomous state.
Demonstrated the increasing power of **corporate-backed private armies** in colonial conflicts.
political: Marked the complete Dutch takeover of Borneo’s lucrative gold trade.
Qing Dynasty failed to protect overseas Chinese populations, leading to weakened influence in Southeast Asia.
cultural: The legacy of the Lanfang Republic is still remembered by Hakka Chinese communities.
Highlighted how Chinese immigrants established self-governing communities in foreign lands.
